title: Mayor says he’ll push for Mother Cabrini statue after heated exchange with actor Chazz Palminteri
text:
STATEN ISLAND, N.Y. -- Mayor Bill de Blasio agreed Friday morning to push for a statue of America’s first saint as part of the second round of a city program aimed at honoring women.

St. Frances Xavier Cabrini, commonly known as Mother Cabrini, was not among the first seven women selected for a statue in the “She Built NYC” initiative despite garnering the highest number of public nominations.

The mayor agreed to make the push in a sometimes contentious conversation with actor Chazz Palminteri during de Blasio’s weekly appearance on “The Brian Lehrer Show.”

“I will guarantee you another round of statues is coming and real soon. Mother Cabrini is right at the top of the list for consideration.” de Blasio said. “I will make a strong case for Mother Cabrini.”

The conversation between the two Italian-Americans became heated over Palminteri’s comments last week on his perceived racism on the part of city First Lady Chirlane McCray, who launched the initiative in June 2018 with Deputy Mayor Alicia Glen and the Department of Cultural Affairs.

Palminteri apologized to de Blasio and asked for the mayor to relay the apology to his wife, which the mayor agreed to do thanking the actor for his apology.

St. Cabrini garnered a total 219 nominations, while urban activist Jane Jacobs, who was also not selected, received the second-highest number of nominations with 93. America’s first black Congresswoman Shirley Anita Chisholm, who represented Brooklyn, was selected after receiving the third-most nominations with 91.

A City Hall spokeswoman pointed out earlier this week that the call for public nominations was not a voting process, and that many other factors were considered as part of the initiative.

Along with Chisholm, jazz singer Billie Holiday, early civil rights figure Elizabeth Jennings Graham, Dr. Helen Rodriguez Trías, lighthouse keeper Katherine Walker, and early LGBTQ activists Marsha Johnson and Sylvia Rivera were selected in the first round of honorees.

MAYOR INFORMS MALLIOTAKIS

Assemblywoman Nicole Malliotakis (R-East Shore/South Brooklyn) also announced Friday that she had been contacted by the mayor’s office, which informed her that there will be another round of statues, and that Mother Cabrini is still being considered.

“I am glad that they are reconsidering their decision and listening to the countless Catholics and Italian-Americans, as well as elected officials, who are pushing to get Mother Cabrini her rightfully-deserved statue in city public space,” she said.

“As both a woman and daughter of immigrants, I believe it is fitting that our city recognize the many contributions Mother Cabrini made for new immigrants, children and those suffering with illness.”

Mother Cabrini is the patron saint of immigrants, and founded an upstate orphanage, a school for girls in Washington Heights and dozens of organizations for the needy.

In a letter to the Advance published Thursday, Malliotakis asked why Cabrini wasn’t being honored despite receiving the most public nominations.

Rep. Max Rose (D-Staten Island/South Brooklyn), whose seat Malliotakis is running for in the 2020 election, has voiced similar frustrations with the city over the perceived snub of Mother Cabrini.

“It’s absurd for the Mayor’s office to solicit public input and then completely ignore the community,” he said Tuesday.
